conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks light; shape and size depend on object shape and light source position.
The size of the shadow is influenced by the distance between the object and the light source.
Current position of the light source is not specified, but it is at a certain height above the objects.
As the light source moves upward, shadows will move closer to the objects due to more vertical light rays.
When the light source moves upward, shadows will become smaller due to more parallel light rays.
Shadow A (Apple) will move slightly closer to the apple and become smaller.
Shadow B (Paper) will move closer to the paper and become smaller.
Shadow C (Glass) will move closer to the glass and become smaller.
Shadow D (Drumstick) will move closer to the drumstick and become smaller.
Final answer: Shadows (A, B, C, and D) will move closer to their respective objects and become smaller.
